Text:
Which isn't true, renegotiating that is. The problem with the use of that term is that it is a general one and thus prone to conflation. Redoing and changing all terms is renegotiation. Doing it to one particular clause/section is also renegotiation. So which is he referring to? I doubt many are referring to the former when they say "renegotiate". The concern always has been the movement of people, not so much other sections such as tariffs and regulations relating to entry of foreign firms.

If what he said is true, then why are we on the third review of ceca? A review by definition and in effect, is a renegotiation of sorts since it involves amending, adding and deleting terms. That's how agreements work. So far, all three reviews have been called for by whom? Us? If so, then aren't we being hypocrites since cotton chan claims that "renegotiation" will reduce confidence? If they were requested by the ceca side, then shouldn't we have less confidence in them for trying to change the terms multiple times? In the previous review, cecaland pushed for more of their educational institutions to be recognized here, in particular nursing. Aren't they changing the terms as well? Why is that considered ok but us wanting to reduce the flow from there isn't?

Also, this begs another question. Why the hell did we agree to such ambiguous terms in the first place that they ended up using it against us? Made bad decision is "ok" but no attempt at recovery is inexcusable. Cotton chan is giving me the impression that he is essentially saying "It was poor judgement on our part when it came to certain terms in the agreement but we can't do anything about it". 

Some people like to conflate matters by making it a race issue and dragging in other countries. Why not China, why not Malaysia(that form the largest)? Simple. India is the ONLY country out of all our trading partners that tried to restrict our sovereign right of protecting our domestic labour market. Worse still, they stated that their interpretation of the agreement is one of no limits and quotas. That is to say, as long as meet stated pass(EP) requirements, shouldn't apply any other hidden limits such as local/ft proportion of the company. Name me another country that has done so? They can't because no other country did. In other words, cecland stirred the matter with us and placed the cross hairs on their own backs. That's what those who claim we "pick nationality" conveniently ignore. They pretend as if the dislike came out of nowhere or is racially motivated.

They also seem to be forgetting that before the 2011 election, the focus was on the tiongs and pinoys but hardly anything about ceca. Why the shift? Because MIW likes to play dumb and do "flavour of the month". They know we didn't like so many tiongs and pinoys so they assumed we would be okay with replacing more of them with cecas. We aren't. What the MIW doesn't get(intentionally or otherwise) is that we are not okay with so many FTs here regardless of where they source it from. If next time round they try to replace ceca with more amdk, we will still be complaining all the same. Same goes for JHK but singaporeans in general more accepting of JHK and thus give more leeway because we have a common history and culture and no other countries even come close to the bond we share with Malaysia. As such, which nationality singaporeans in general focus on is also dependent on which the gahment decides to take in more of during that particular period.

No limits and quotas, let that sink in. India with 1.3b people. If we even took in 0.01% of their people by way of them transferring existing staff here and taking on new ones for their home office, we will be absolutely swamped.

The much talked ICT terms are not exactly high barriers of entry either despite supposedly intended for HIGHLY experienced and skilled staff. Here are the conditions:

1) At least six months with the company + 1 year industry experience

OR

2)3 years industry experience preceding the date of application.

6 months with company + 1 year industrial exp? Seriously? A  fresh grad new hire can easily meet that. 6 months with a company is about as long as probation period in some companies. It is also the duration fo a typical poly attachment. 3 years is very short too. If my interpretation of it is correct, it means ceca company can essentially send a fresh hire here because the 3 years exp seems to be separate from the 6 mth with company requirement. 

Even more worrying is the gahment's seemingly reluctance to put their foot down on the matter. Their response to cecaland's complaints has been relatively mute . When cecaland celebrated that most of their companies were taken off the FCF watchlist, why did we do that? Was it because they actually rectified the issue or was it because our side bowed to the pressure and closed one eye instead? Also, was a company like tata consultancy that started with only 20% local ever put on the list? If not, why? Text:
One just need to juxtapose the current situation in Singapore with the situation in Hong Kong - a similar sized economy, with similar economic demographics and facing similar global financial headwinds as well as economic challenges because of the CV19 pandemic.

Key differences exposed by the CV19 economic crisis, are the hiring practices between Singapore and Hong Kong.

In Hong Kong, the local Hong Kongers and Chinese nationals are all gainfully employed in good jobs and well-paid MNCs positions. 

Local Hong Kongers are always considered ahead of FTs for both junior and senior roles at MNCs bought in by the same foreign investments that Singapore is competing for in the Asia-Pacific.

Consequently, expats in HK are facing less of a backlash today because there had been a good balance.  

Both local Hong Kongers and HK expats genuinely see each other as equal and complementary - unlike the lips-service paid by the LHL's Administration that everything they did, they did it for Singaporeans when in actual practice foreigners were put on a pedestal ahead of its own citizens.

Cold hard numbers that foreigners occupied the majority of senior positions in Singapore's banking & finance industry are a fact.

And figures that showed foreigners are collectively paying more income taxes than all of Singaporean workers do not lie and simply showed that foreigners had been getting the good and well-paid jobs in Singapore.

Worse the LHL's administration recent desperate attempts to selectively reveal figures that Singaporeans are "at the core" of certain companies or industries holding 60%, 70%, 80% of all the jobs there simply showed up further that Singaporeans got the lower paid jobs in their own country when a lesser number of foreigners could carry the bigger income tax burden in Singapore.

Just take a look at the example of the MNCs bank that proclaim that it's "here for good". 

Same MNC HQ, same bank but with vastly different employee demographics in two different jurisdiction.

The Hong Kong SAR administration actually strike a very good balance between employing and developing local talent and the need to stay open globally to foreign talents over the years. 

One of my colleague actually needed to wait for four months before his Hong Kong's GEP - Professionals visa application was checked, scrutinised and approved.

It's four months! Not 4-6 working days in Singapore's case.

And he's not a nobody armed with a bona fide Uptron certificate.  

He is somebody whom the firm is willing to write in his employment contract that he's allowed to take up to 10 days a year off work just to pursue his passion of windsurfing whenever the winds forecast is above 18 knots the next day.

So yes, the LHL's administration had bought this upon themselves today. 

And Singapore and Singaporean had to suffer yet again for their mismanagement and "fog of war" excuses just like the initial mismanagement of the CV19 situation in Singapore.
